skill.name: chronicle-assistant-guide
skill.description: Project-agnostic guidance for AI assistants using Chronicle. Provides search-first directives, best practices, and workflow patterns across ALL Chronicle-tracked projects. Works with or without MCP server.
skill.summary: Project-agnostic guidance for AI assistants using Chronicle. Provides search-first directives, best ...
skill.author: ChandlerHardy

security_audit.summary: Pure documentation skill with no executable code. Contains only markdown guidance for using Chronicle session tracking. No file access, network calls, or command execution capabilities.

content.value_statement: Chronicle tracks every AI session, creating a searchable history of your work. This guide provides essential directives for AI assistants to leverage past sessions, avoid repeated mistakes, and follow proven workflows.
actual_capabilities: Search past Chronicle sessions for context before implementing features
Use MCP tools for fast structured queries when available
Fall back to CLI commands when MCP server is unavailable
Check project roadmap and milestones before starting work
Debug issues by searching for similar past problems
Understand session relationships and project history
limitations: Does not execute Chronicle commands - only provides guidance
Requires Chronicle to be installed and configured
MCP server must be running for fastest tool access
Cannot create or modify sessions - only reads existing data

use_cases.title: Search before implementing
use_cases.description: Search past sessions to avoid repeating mistakes and learn from previous solutions before starting new work

use_cases.title: Understand project history
use_cases.description: Review session summaries and timeline to understand how features were implemented and why decisions were made

use_cases.title: Find similar past issues
use_cases.description: Search for error messages or symptoms to discover how similar problems were solved in previous sessions

prompt_templates.prompt: How do I use Chronicle to search past sessions and understand project context?

prompt_templates.title: Search for context

prompt_templates.title: View roadmap
prompt_templates.prompt: Show me the current roadmap and milestones for this project

output_examples.input: How do I use Chronicle to search past sessions?
output: Before implementing anything, search Chronicle first. This saves time by finding solutions already discovered in past sessions.
With CLI: Run chronicle search "your keywords" --limit 5
Check related sessions in search results for full context and solutions

best_practices: Always search Chronicle before implementing features or debugging issues
Use MCP tools for fast structured responses when available, fall back to CLI
Read session summaries to understand past approaches and avoid repeated mistakes
anti_patterns: Jumping straight into implementation without searching for related past work
Ignoring related sessions in search results
Forgetting to check the roadmap before creating new milestones

faq.question: What AI tools support this skill?
faq.answer: Works with Claude, Codex, and Claude Code. MCP tools require Chronicle MCP server running.

faq.question: Does this skill execute commands?
faq.answer: No. It provides guidance only. Chronicle must be installed separately to execute commands.

faq.question: How does MCP differ from CLI?
faq.answer: MCP provides fast structured JSON responses under 10ms. CLI uses subprocess calls around 100ms but works everywhere.

faq.question: Is my session data stored safely?
faq.answer: Chronicle stores sessions locally in ~/.ai-session/ directory. No data is sent to external servers.

faq.question: What if MCP server is not available?
faq.answer: All functionality works via CLI commands. Chronicle searches, roadmap, and sessions all support CLI fallback.

faq.question: How is this different from other skills?
faq.answer: This skill is project-agnostic and works across ALL Chronicle-tracked projects. It provides universal directives for any project using Chronicle.
